name: Yeah Yeah Yeahs
description:
'''Yeah Yeah Yeahs''' are an American [[indie rock]] band formed in [[New York City]] in 2000. The group consists of vocalist/pianist [[Karen O]], guitarist/keyboardist [[Nick Zinner]], and drummer [[Brian Chase]]. The band's energetic performances and blend of genres made them key figures of the 2000s [[garage rock]] and [[Post-punk revival|post-punk movements]]. They do not have a bassist but have been supported by [[David Pajo]] and [[Imaad Wasif]] during live performances.

Yeah Yeah Yeahs began recording in 2001 and achieved their international breakthrough with their debut album, ''[[Fever to Tell]]'', in 2003. Its sales were boosted by the single "[[Maps (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Maps]]", which became the band's [[List of signature songs|signature song]]. They issued a second album, ''[[Show Your Bones]]'' (2006), and shifted to [[dance-punk]] with their third, ''[[It's Blitz!]]'' (2009); both records received positive reviews and produced the singles "[[Gold Lion]]", "[[Zero (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Zero]]", "[[Heads Will Roll (song)|Heads Will Roll]]", and "[[Skeletons (Yeah Yeah Yeahs song)|Skeletons]]". Their fourth album, ''[[Mosquito (album)|Mosquito]]'' (2013), became their highest-charting record in the United States but did not match the reception of its predecessors. The group went on a hiatus the following year and returned in 2017, performing live for the rest of the 2010s. Their fifth and most recent album, ''[[Cool It Down]]'' (2022), was released to critical acclaim. It produced the digital hit "[[Spitting Off the Edge of the World]]".

Yeah Yeah Yeahs have received [[List of awards and nominations received by Yeah Yeah Yeahs|several accolades]], including nominations for five [[Grammy Awards]]—four of which were for [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]]—and seven [[MTV Video Music Awards]]. ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' included ''Fever to Tell'' on their list of the "[[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|500 Greatest Albums of All Time]]" and "Maps" on their "[[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|500 Greatest Songs of All Time]]".
